results.title: Queer as folk 2. What the folk...?
results.creator_credit: Nicola Shindler, Russell T. Davies, Menhaj Huda, Channel Four and Red Productions
results.brief_description: Follow up to the controversial British series which follows the trials and sexual exploits of a group of gay men in London. This second series was created as a one off finale and re-teams the three main protagonists from the first season. The hedonistic Stuart (Aidan Gillan), his long suffering best friend Vince (Craig Kelly), and the recently ‘out’ teenager Nathan (Charlie Hunnam). “Queer as folk 2” still focuses on the same milieu of Canal street, the gay district of the first series, but this time around centers on the relationship between Vince and Stuart. Will the two best friends finally consummate their relationship? Will Stuart come out to his parents? Will the impressionistic Nathan finally get over Stuart or follow in his footsteps? Also included is “What the folk…?” (25 mins), a short documentary on the making of the infamous series featuring interviews with the leads and writer Russell T. Davies. Cast includes Denise Black, Antony Cotton and Andy Devine.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Nicola Shindler, Russell T. Davies, Menhaj Huda, Channel Four and Red Productions

results.title: Queensland Centenary Story, 1859-1959
results.creator_credit: Dulcie Holland, Eric Thompson, Judy Campbell, Malcolm Otton and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: A brief account of the first hundred years of Queensland’s history, touching on its social life, its connection with two world wars, its industries and its agricultural and pastoral pursuits. Many sequences of historical intrest - in particular the visit of the Prince of Wales in 1921 and the Trans-Pacific flight by Sir Charles Kingsford Smith.

results.title: Queen Elizabeth 2 sails around New Zealand and Australia
results.brief_description: Doug Jones sets sail with the QE2 for a voyage ‘down under’ to New Zealand and Australia. He explores Rotorua and its geothermal world of mudpots, geysers and steaming lakes and cliffs, the Tasman Galcier in a ski plane , as well as visiting Auckland, Wellington, Christchurch and Queenstown. In Australia the Sydney Opera House is visited, as is a sheep station while shearing is underway. A behind the scenes look is taken at life aboard the ship from the bridge and the engine control centre to the largest floating kitchens in the world.

results.title: Public hangings. Series 1. Ep. 10
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Public hangings”.
Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie along with co-presenter Lena Corner, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode Lena Corner rounds up the mood of the Next Wave Festival opening to then look at the collaborative community project from the program ‘Moving Along’ and the performance of ‘The Angels’ who took up residency on Melbourne’s State Theatre spire for a ten day period whilst doing performances on the spire over that time. ‘Neo Noir’ curated by Mark Feary opens at Gertrude Contemporary Art Space with artists; Sharon Goodwin, Matthew Griffin, Amanda Marburg, Kate Just, Sarah Lynch, Camilla Hannan, Van Sowerwine. Three works at CCP are investigated; ‘Play With Me’, ‘Skin Club’ and ‘Solid Estate’. This week’s Screen Talk features the work ‘Human machine landscape’ by Simon Price and Simon Terrill shown at Fortyfivedownstairs.

results.title: Public hangings. Series 1. Ep. 13
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “Public hangings”.
Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie along with co-presenter Lena Corner, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode, Andrew MacKenzie presents a show of his favourite bits from the first series. This includes: The opening of the Helen Lempriere National Sculpture Prize, ‘Neo Noir’ at Gertrude Contemporary Art Spaces, ‘Art Bites’ community project in Parkdale, ‘Comic Book Lifestyle’ Linden St Kilda Centre for Contemporary Arts, Sticky - the comic book shop and James Meldrum at Mira Gallery.

results.title: Public hangings. Series 1. Ep. 11
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “Public hangings”.
Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie along with co-presenter Lena Corner, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode Lena Corner interviews Sue Wyers in her studio and talks about the ‘honoured object’ and ‘domains of defiance’, themes related to Wyers’ work. Rod Quantock is the talking head at Span Galleries opening of the ‘Artful Dodgers’ revealing the Xena photographs as his favourite. RMIT gallery opens its retrospective of internationally renowned German artist, Gerhard Richter. The exhibition surveys forty years of Richter’s work using examples that identify ‘touchstones’ for the artist as selected by Richter himself. The works explore the fluid line between the abstract and figurative and use process both as a means and an end. The exhibition at Westspace Gating” is a group show exploring sound technologies. Featured are the works by Michael Graeve, Simon Kilvert (Decent Column), Rhino Lintz and Mark [Marco] Fusinato (2’ 30”). Screen Talk this week features Leslie Eastman whose work is concerned with exploring themes such as; language and time, the objectivity of language and its phenomenon versus conditional experience.

results.title: Public hangings. Series 1. Ep. 09
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Public hangings”.
Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for and broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie and co-presenter Lena Corner roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode: Firstly at RMIT Project Space is the group exhibition by artists Peta Clancy, Sylvia Kranawetvogl, Erik Hable and James Cecil called “Body Manufacture”, an exhibition in response to the 1974 discovery in geneology of the chromosome. The exhibition seeks to explore the ‘sexing’ of scientific imagery and the publics’ relationship to images of the intangible and abstract. At Mira Gallery, James Meldrum talks about his practice and ‘letting go..’ and the NGV hosts another year of ‘Top Arts’, an exhibition of Victoria’s top art folio’s submitted by Year 12 VCE students. Screen Talk this episode focuses on Media Art Graduate work: Joel Zika’s ‘In the woods’ is a sombre abstraction with a soundscape that brings our ears close to the ground with elements reminiscent of Len Lye’s kinetic metal sculptures. Anne Perri’s ‘The Erotica shakes me’ is a play on the banality of neon signs and the desire to construct meaning. ‘On the way home’ by Isobel and Jeremy digitally constructs silhoutted imagery in a style made famous by Lotte Reiniger.

results.title: Quebec: duplessis et apres...
results.creator_credit: Paul Larose and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film establishes a parallel between the 1970 electoral campaign in Quebec and the 1936 campaign dominated by Maurice Duplessis. It shows the hope but also the uncertainty that existed in 1970. Had the Quiet Revolution really changed things in Quebec? Was it possible that a new leader would emerge on the political scene?

results.title: Quayside
results.brief_description: The Quayside was the old commercial area in Newcastle. It is now under threat from the redeveloper’s hammer. The film is a poetic lament about its past while indicating fears for its future. Elaborate tracking devices were used in making the film and a soundtrack constructed from files found in old shipping offices.

results.title: Public hangings. Series 1. Ep. 12
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Public hangings”.
Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie along with co-presenter Lena Corner, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode Lena Corner interviews Luke Sinclair and Anya Latham about their evolving autobiographical (and collaborative) set of installations at Platform. Melbourne City Councils ‘Laneways Project’ is launched with the work of David Williams and Carol Porter whose collaborative public work looks at the Chinese role in the Melbourne community by exploring the history of the Chen family, early Melbourne settlers. Andrew Stevens talks about his not-for-profit art space in Footscray, ‘Shopfront’. John-Paul Hussey performs his critically reviewed autobiographical one-man show ‘The Chocolate Monkey’ at Gammaspace. Screen Talk this week looks at the video work of Starlie Gieki whose work centres around themes of victimhood and the image of women.
